ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: This course was very well organized, especially considering the many goals it set out to accomplish, which it did.
The organization was clear: generally, discuss readings for the first part of the class, then talk about people's projects. It was clearly organized, it just wasn't stimulating or time well-spent.

*Sequence of syllabus well thought out *Good at having mini-deadlines, especially for crafting the larger research project *Great having the longer play broken up--allows us to get into a bigger discussion instead of having to compress a closer reading into vague sound bytes
I knew what was going to happen every week. Scott presented that in the first week and we never strayed from that plan.

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
comments: The discussions about the readings were really productive, and the instructor was keen not to let the occasional laziness on the part of the students interfere with digging into the readings. I do wish we had a little more time to discuss and question the student presenters, but overall the balance between instruction and discussion was very productive.
There was very little instruction of substance.

*Though the class was at times unwilling to talk, this was through no fault of the professor. He tried. Hard. To get us to speak. And Scott was excellent at providing questions/comments that would facilitate dialogue even when some of us were rather (why were we?) taciturn.

narratives.question_text: How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: I feel much more confident about submitting papers to conferences, putting together an academic panel, and constructing a bibliography than I did before the course.

The assignments didn't really teach us anything about research. I do not feel better situated to approach comps and/or orals. "Learning" how to format a footnote is not a worthwhile course goal. I don't feel that I learned anything new from any of the assignments. Doing the practice "conference presentation" may have been useful for some people.

I think a course like this--that is, one which first year PhD students would take in their five/six-year programs--is essential, even for people who will only complete the MFA portion of our Dramaturgy program. Knowing how to write an academic paper, how to give a conference talk, and how to do research isn't intuitive knowledge we all come into this program already having. This class and its mission was as close as I felt all year to being close to proper academia, and heaven forbid that should happen in a three-year MFA program. Some people might complain that this was too academic(icky), but I say that a program like ours has a responsibility to give us ALL equal training, no matter our intended final area of focus. This program has a great task of balancing different career tracks, different practices, and a class like Research Methodologies (perhaps poorly titled) has an important counterbalancing role to play in a program of study that has six years of criticism classes that focus not on academic writing but writing for magazines, the art of writing, etc. (all of which is great and I love and is definitely a strength of our program). The academic research paper is its own beast, that should be tackled honestly and with full force. Our program should be as competent as any other humanities PhD and as any other (arts) MFA. While some might say that we write enough term papers for our academic courses, I say that none of these term papers come with a whole semester-long course on how to write them. Writing a research paper shouldn't have to be just a frantic end-of-the-year exercise in regurgitation and poorly done research. All dramaturgs (at YSD) should know what it means to enter a scholarly debate. It can only make the quality of our thought better, and will put us right on par with other institutions of higher learning (see Chicago's one-year MA in the Humanities and NYU's one-year MA in Performance Studies).
I would say half of the assigned reading helped me in my research endeavors. Much of the reading overlapped with theory (particularly the performance studies reading.

Though the original syllabus had some projects that felt separate from the aims of the course (writing a program note, for example), Scott was willing to drop it so that we could focus on the long-term research project.

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: We discussed each reading during class, which was very helpful to understanding many of the major theoretical approaches that are operative in the Academy today. Having a student do a précis for each of the readings was also very productive and helped prompt the discussions.

It was too much reading. For the most part the reading was far outside the field, so we were only reading it for the sake of the discussion rather than a larger purpose. But the discussions never felt all that worthwhile (I don't think we needed practice at "applying" literary theory to dramatic texts; this is something we do all the time without practice, and learned how to do in college). So it felt like a lot of unnecessary readying.

*The amount of reading assigned was PERFECT. Other dramaturgy courses that favor breadth over depth could take some notes from this class's precise syllabus. *As for the assigned reading itself, I felt that the critical reading we did often was shoehorned into a discussion of the primary text. Maybe there are more fitting theories to read? Or conversely, more fitting plays for the theory?
We covered all of the assigned reading in class.
Having Lindsay King come to class and talk about online tools to help build a bibliography was very helpful!

For the sake of this question I'm considering the websites we looked at to be "supplementary materials." The most worthwhile part of the course was the various web resources (ie. digital humanities sites, "the professor is in," etc.). But we could have just been given a list of these sites rather than spending class time on looking at them.

*Lindsay King is an asset to any classroom. She was a great resource for our research. *Going to the NYPL Performing Arts Library (even though I didn't get to go with the class due to a work-study conflict for the Rep) is a great trip to make. Sometimes people don't know the wealth of resources available to them. Maybe there should be a requirement to have some of this archival research become part of the research paper??? That way the trip could serve some grander purpose than just a visit. I've been to that library before as an undergraduate and was asked to incorporate part of my research there into my term paper. It was a tough experience scheduling wise but completely worth it. *Maybe the class can ditch the close reading of plays in favor of having a course focused on writing an academic research paper including conference papers, talks, etc. This would involve trips to do primary research either here at our wonderful libraries or New York. It would definitely be more interactive and perhaps fruitful for all parties involved, even those who consider themselves exclusively production dramaturgs. Everyone wins! Also, it could be a great exercise before casebooks in the third year. *The course should take RESEARCH to heart. How do we do it? Where do we do it? An advantage of this course was having us read contemporary theory being written in academic circles. This is essential, especially for those of us catching up to the current conversations being had in our discipline.
I think the media elements that my fellow classmates integrated into their projects really helped me to grasp what they were working on.

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: This course is essential a class on how to be an academic, and the knowledge I gained from it helped me to understand the opportunities that are available to advance my academic career.
I think my responses above sufficiently answer this question. I don't think I learned anything from this course.

*Class was a good way of getting into contemporary academic conversations surrounding performance *There's still room for improving the course and having us really dig into what it means to do research. See all above comments

I think some of the research techniques that were covered were illuminating such as the digital humanities archives and tools. However, some of the theory was repetitive when taken in conjunction with theory.

Personally, I feel as though I have had educational experiences that has exposed me to the theoretical readings and archival and digital humanities research discussed in the course. But I do think it probably filled knowledge gaps for several of my classmates.

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: If someone is interested in being an academic, this is a great course.
No.

*I think my above statements have made it clear that YES every dramaturg should take this class and that the department should strengthen the curriculum explored in this course. *BE RIGOROUS PLEASE!!!
I would not recommend this class for people unless it is not a theory year.

I would probably not recommend it to students outside of the department because of the level and amount of theoretical reading and department-specific foundation that I think is needed to succeed in it.
I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to those outside of dramaturgy except for select people who are more academically minded

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: The goals of the course are hard to articulate, and the course is trying to accomplish multiple things at once. Overall, however, I think the instructor did a great job of being clear that this course was about practicing giving presentations, writing papers, and creating reference materials (bibliographies, etc.). Secondly, the course was about familiarizing the students with major theoretical approaches that people are currently using (Derrida, Judith Butler, Joseph Roach, etc.) and how these theoretical frameworks might inform a reading of a theater text.

They weren't presented. I only feel like I have a sense of the goals from speaking with other faculty and students who took the course (or suggested the need for the course) in years past. The goal of the course, as I understand it, was to help us prepare for comps/orals/academic papers. I would not have known this from the course itself, though.

*I say "average" because while the goals were clearly presented by the instructor, I feel that the goals themselves could be clearer. Right now RM seems a bit all over the place. What is the class's place in the overall dramaturgy curriculum? FACULTY PLEASE TAKE A STANCE! This should not be a filler course. In fact none of our courses should be filler. All are essential!
I think the goals and structure of the course, as well as its connection to the overall dramaturgy curriculum could have been more clearly presented.

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
comments: I was pleasantly surprised at the command that the instructor had on the material, considering that his background was not in theater.

While he clearly knew how to do "academic" stuff, being from a field outside of theater was problematic. Additionally, being unfamiliar with the specifics of YSD and the dramaturgy program was a hindrance.

*As someone who does research and recently graduated from his own program of study, Scott is well-trained in academic-ese and was able to give us a holistic view of doing research in an academic setting. *Scott also showed great interest in performance and how his own discipline crossed over into ours.
Scott was able to tell us a lot about the job hunting process and the digital humanities aspect of the class.

narratives.question_text: The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: Instruction was minimal.
*The syllabus could have been questioned more. *What are the connections between the primary texts and the secondary readings? Sometimes these weren't explicit or seemed forced.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
comments: Sure.
*Incredibly flexible and giving professor *Really tried his best at catering to our wants for the class

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
comments: Sure.
*See above

narratives.question_text: The grading criteria was clearly explained.
comments: I think it was explained? I don't really remember.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
comments: The instructor always responded to my email inquiries in a timely fashion, and his response and feedback to my draft abstract was really helpful.
I'm not sure. He was not available at Yale for such things, seeing as he was only on campus during class meeting times, but I imagine he would be available to remotely if needed.
*Scott checked his emails frequently and got back to us within the same day

narratives.question_text: I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: I would not recommend him for this class. However, I don't think that's entirely his fault. He seems like a nice, fun, smart professor. However, I imagine he'd be great in his own field in a course he designed. It felt like he was shoe-horned into teaching this course, and working with a syllabus designed by someone else, with unclear goals, while being unfamiliar with the students, procedures, and environment of YSD. Scott was lovely; as a teacher of this course, he was ineffective.

Scott is an excellent professor. He is always looking to go the extra mile for his students (he even offered to set up a grant writing tutorial with one of his colleagues at NYU). He is open to questions and suggestions throughout the course.
Though the course was clearly in the process of becoming, Scott was a very knowledge and enthusiastic instructor.

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
comments: All.
All
ALL
All
All 14 class meetings.

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: The instructor very much wanted class presentations to be memorized or to work from a minimum of notes. While in actual conference presentations this is a valuable practice, I did wonder if it hurt the quality of the presentations that people were bringing in. I wonder if the material presented would have actually been more compelling, because it would have been much better organized and articulated, if people had been allowed essentially to read something they had prepared. I found memorizing or paraphrasing my nascent research in any way very daunting and I'm sure it made the material I was presenting far less coherent.

As reflected by my comment above, this course needs a total revamp. As it is, it is almost useless and the worthwhile material could be conveyed in a 2-hour seminar rather than a full-semester course.
ALL OF THE ABOVE

If this course is about effective means of research, lean into that aspect of the course. I felt like too much of my time in this course was spent trying to wrap my head around theory that was either not helpful or that we were going to cover in Elinor's theory class later.

I really enjoyed almost all aspects of the course. However, sometimes I felt that the goal of deploying various critical models in the reading of plays and the goal of preparing a research paper were really two separate goals, and deserved two courses (perhaps one a crit class. I could see combining the multiple-reading-models curriculum with "Baby Crit", which at times felt methodologically ungrounded.
